Atom: The basic unit of a chemical element.
Binary: A system of numerical notation that has 2 as a base.
Canopy: The uppermost layer of a forest formed by tree crowns.
Dynasty: A line of hereditary rulers of a country.
Euphoria: A feeling or state of intense excitement and happiness.
Fusion: The process of merging two or more entities into one.
Galaxy: A vast system of stars, dust, and gas bound by gravity.
Habitat: The natural environment in which an organism lives.
Innovation: The introduction of new ideas or methods.
Jungle: A dense forest in a tropical climate.
Kinetic: Related to or resulting from motion.
Longitude: The angular distance of a place east or west of the prime meridian.
Metaphor: A figure of speech in which a word is applied to an object it does not literally belong to.
Nebula: A cloud of gas and dust in outer space.
Oxygen: A chemical element essential for life on Earth.
Photosynthesis: The process used by plants to convert light into energy.
Quantum: The minimum amount of any physical entity involved in an interaction.
Relativity: A theory by Einstein explaining space, time, and gravity.
Symbiosis: A close relationship between two different organisms.
Terraform: To modify a planet to support life like Earth.
Umbra: The fully shaded inner region of a shadow.
Vortex: A mass of whirling fluid or air.
Wavelength: The distance between successive crests of a wave.
Xenon: A chemical element used in specialized lamps.
Zenith: The highest point reached in the sky by a celestial object.
Algorithm: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or performing a task.
Blockchain: A decentralized digital ledger used in cryptocurrency transactions.
Catalyst: A substance that speeds up a chemical reaction without being consumed.
Dendrite: A branch-like structure in neurons that receives signals.
Eclipse: An event where one celestial body moves into the shadow of another.
Fractal: A complex geometric pattern that repeats at different scales.
Genomics: The study of an organism's complete set of DNA, including its genes.
Hydrology: The scientific study of water movement, distribution, and quality.
Inertia: A property of matter that resists changes in motion.
Joule: A unit of energy in the International System of Units (SI).
Keystone: A central, supporting element in an arch or system.
Lattice: A repeating arrangement of atoms, ions, or molecules in a crystal.
Momentum: The quantity of motion an object has, dependent on mass and velocity.
Neuron: A nerve cell that transmits electrical and chemical signals in the body.
Oscillation: A repetitive variation in position, magnitude, or state over time.
Photon: A quantum of light or other electromagnetic radiation.
Quasar: A distant, extremely bright celestial object powered by a black hole.
Resonance: A phenomenon where a system vibrates at a specific frequency.
Supernova: A powerful stellar explosion that occurs at the end of a star’s lifecycle.
Turbulence: Irregular or chaotic fluid motion, often seen in air and water currents.
Uranium: A radioactive element used as fuel in nuclear reactors.
Xylem: A type of tissue in plants that transports water from roots to leaves.
Yield Strength: The stress at which a material begins to deform permanently.
Aerosol: A suspension of fine solid particles or liquid droplets in air or another gas.
Buoyancy: The ability of an object to float in a fluid due to upward force.
Cryosphere: The frozen water part of the Earth system, including ice caps and glaciers.
Diffraction: The bending of waves around obstacles or through openings.
Entropy: A measure of disorder or randomness in a system.
Fibonacci: A sequence in which each number is the sum of the two preceding ones.
Glucose: A simple sugar that serves as a primary energy source for living organisms.
Holography: A technique to create three-dimensional images using laser light.
Igneous: A type of rock formed from the solidification of molten lava or magma.
Jigsaw: A puzzle in which interlocking pieces form a picture when assembled.
Kilobyte: A unit of digital information storage equal to 1024 bytes.
Lithosphere: The rigid outer layer of the Earth, consisting of the crust and upper mantle.
Magnetism: A physical phenomenon produced by the motion of electric charges.
Nucleotide: The basic structural unit of DNA and RNA.
Optics: The branch of physics concerned with light and vision.
Polymorphism: The ability of an object or function to take on different forms in programming.
Quintessence: The most perfect or typical example of a quality or class.
Radiation: The emission of energy as electromagnetic waves or particles.
Semiconductor: A material with conductivity between conductors and insulators, used in electronics.
Tectonics: The study of Earth's structural features and movements.
Ultraviolet: A type of electromagnetic radiation with a wavelength shorter than visible light.
Viscosity: A measure of a fluid’s resistance to flow.
Ytterbium: A chemical element used in lasers and nuclear applications.
Zygote: A fertilized cell formed by the union of sperm and egg.
